1use super::{fmt, Cow, Options, State};
2
3pub fn padding<F>(f: &mut F, p: &[Cow<'_, str>]) -> fmt::Result
4where
5    F: fmt::Write,
6{
7    for padding in p {
8        write!(f, "{padding}")?;
9    }
10    Ok(())
11}
12pub fn consume_newlines<F>(f: &mut F, s: &mut State<'_>) -> fmt::Result
13where
14    F: fmt::Write,
15{
16    while s.newlines_before_start != 0 {
17        s.newlines_before_start -= 1;
18        f.write_char('\n')?;
19        padding(f, &s.padding)?;
20    }
21    Ok(())
22}
23
24pub fn escape_special_characters<'a>(t: &'a str, state: &State<'a>, options: &Options<'a>) -> Cow<'a, str> {
25    if state.is_in_code_block() || t.is_empty() {
26        return Cow::Borrowed(t);
27    }
28
29    let first = t.chars().next().expect("at least one char");
30    let first_special = options.special_characters().contains(first);
31    let ends_with_special =
32        (state.next_is_link_like && t.ends_with("!")) || (state.current_heading.is_some() && t.ends_with("#"));
33    let table_contains_pipe = !state.table_alignments.is_empty() && t.contains("|");
34    if first_special || ends_with_special || table_contains_pipe {
35        let mut s = String::with_capacity(t.len() + 1);
36        for (i, c) in t.char_indices() {
37            if (i == 0 && first_special) || (i == t.len() - 1 && ends_with_special) || (c == '|' && table_contains_pipe)
38            {
39                s.push('\\');
40            }
41            s.push(c);
42        }
43        Cow::Owned(s)
44    } else {
45        Cow::Borrowed(t)
46    }
47}
48
49pub fn print_text_without_trailing_newline<F>(t: &str, f: &mut F, p: &[Cow<'_, str>]) -> fmt::Result
50where
51    F: fmt::Write,
52{
53    let line_count = t.split('\n').count();
54    for (tid, token) in t.split('\n').enumerate() {
55        f.write_str(token)?;
56        if tid + 1 < line_count {
57            f.write_char('\n')?;
58            padding(f, p)?;
59        }
60    }
61    Ok(())
62}
63
64pub fn padding_of(l: Option<u64>) -> Cow<'static, str> {
65    match l {
66        None => "  ".into(),
67        Some(n) => format!("{n}. ").chars().map(|_| ' ').collect::<String>().into(),
68    }
69}
70
71/// Write a newline followed by the current [`State::padding`]
72/// text that indents the current nested content.
73///
74/// [`write_padded_newline()`] takes care of writing both a newline character,
75/// and the appropriate padding characters, abstracting over the need to
76/// carefully pair those actions.
77///
78/// # Purpose
79///
80/// Consider a scenario where we're trying to write out the following Markdown
81/// (space indents visualized as '·'):
82///
83/// ```markdown
84/// >·A block quote with an embedded list:
85/// >·
86/// >·* This is a list item that itself contains
87/// >···multiple lines and paragraphs of content.
88/// >···
89/// >···Second paragraph.
90/// ```
91///
92/// Each line of output within the block quote needs to include the text `">·"`
93/// at the beginning of the line. Additionally, within the list, each line
94/// _also_ needs to start with `"··"` spaces so that the content of the
95/// list item is indented.
96///
97/// Concretely, a call to [`write_padded_newline()`] after the first line in the
98/// paragraph of the list item would write `"\n>···"`.
99pub(crate) fn write_padded_newline(formatter: &mut impl fmt::Write, state: &State<'_>) -> Result<(), fmt::Error> {
100    formatter.write_char('\n')?;
101    padding(formatter, &state.padding)?;
102    Ok(())
103}
